Award.AwardTitle: Maine Mathematics and Science Scholars for School and University Collaboration Centered on Educating STEM Students (SUCCESS)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The Maine Mathematics and Science Scholars for School and University Collaboration Centered on Educating STEM Students (SUCCESS) Program is providing talented students majoring in applied mathematics, chemistry, biology, marine sciences, and environmental sciences at the University of New England (UNE) with four-year scholarships, education programs, mentoring, internship opportunities, and career counseling. The program has five primary objectives: 1) increase the number of meritorious students majoring in STEM programs; 2) provide scholarships to students interested in pursuing a STEM career who may otherwise not be able to attend UNE due to financial constraints; 3) retain STEM students to graduation; 4) develop sustained excellence in undergraduate STEM education; and 5) support SUCCESS Scholars with internships and career counseling. UNE chemistry/physics and mathematical science faculty and staff liaise with faculty and staff from targeted high schools to encourage talented STEM-bound students with demonstrated financial need to apply. The SUCCESS program also includes a weeklong summer bridge program consisting of coursework in mathematics, science, and English, as well as the Trailblazers program, which is designed to increase student appreciation of available natural and human resources and to establish rapport among the participants. Overall, the program facilitates SUCCESS Scholars' ability to obtain local employment in STEM fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
To help address the shortage of qualified candidates in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM), a multi-disciplined team of mathematicians and scientists developed this S-STEM program to attract, recruit, and retain students in collaboration with area high schools. Scholarship funds served to draw and retain academically promising undergraduate students with financial need in applied mathematics, biology, chemistry, marine science, and neuroscience, including first-generation, women, and other historically underrepresented groups in STEM disciplines. The project implemented high-impact, evidence-based academic and cohort-based support programs shown to improve persistence and graduation rates. In particular, students participated in a summer bridge program to ensure college readiness. Freshman cohorts enrolled in a one-credit seminar with hands-on activities, guest lectures, and field trips to gain insight into different STEM career paths. Research opportunities and conference attendance provided students with a sense of professional association and identification. Building upon DUE 0726749, peer-mentoring supported the cohort community by providing both educational support and assistance navigating campus life. Finally, the program leveraged existing campus support services, such as career counseling, with faculty advising. 

Key Outcomes: The SUCCESS program graduated 15 high-quality STEM scholars. The program's overall persistence rate was 62%, more than 10% higher than the national average. Sixty percent have attained employment in a STEM field within the first year after graduation, and one-third are pursuing graduate degrees in a STEM discipline. Results, reflections, recommendations, and program descriptions were disseminated at both regional and national venues.

Intellectual Merit: The program provided additional evidence supporting claims as to the benefits of cohort-based enrichment activities, advantages of both faculty and peer-mentoring, and the importance of undergraduate research to student retention in STEM.

Broader Impacts: The SUCCESS program created both local and regional STEM educational outreach programs in green chemistry and broad-based computer coding aimed at elementary and middle school students. Graduates of the SUCCESS program have entered the workforce (or pursuing further education) in STEM fields contributing to U.S. competitiveness in a global economy. Professional development opportunities for local mathematics teachers contribute to the education of future STEM students.
